name: ST BOOK
ports: Centronics, RS232c, Floppy Disk, internal IDE Hard disk, Midi In/Out, Dock Station connector
description:
After the success of the Stacy, Atari presented a new portable computer: the ST Book.

It was a rather nice toy: very light, impressive battery life, MIDI ports, battery-saved RAM, etc. 

The Hard Disk contains a small Null-Modem program to transfer files (very handy!). It has no internal floppy drive, the external floppy was a weird (and expensive!) unit that used the same interface as Atari's hard disks (ACSI).

Despite its interesting characteristics, and because of the deplorable commercial policy of Atari (I KNOW NUTTZING!), it had no success and only about one thousand units were sold in Europe.

A word of warning: The cases & screen on this computer are VERY FRAGILE! Whatever you do, do not drop this computer, as it probably will shatter!

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> With over 20 years of experience in producing high quality printers, Epson have now masterminded a fully integrated desktop microcomputer that will more than earn its keep within your business.<br> The QX-IO is capable of performing all the tasks you will ever require of it, quickly and efficiently. Installation of the QX-IO can be carried out with the minimum of interruption, and with its easily understandable keyboard, it is simplicity itself to operate. Having such a diverse range of software packages available such as database from Pearl and office productivity and accountancy from Peachtree with CP/M and multifont BASIC as standard, the QX-IO can supply all the answers whatever your business.<br> Just look at what's on offer: a big memory - 192k upgradable to 256k RAM and all the graphics you'll ever need - and high resolution graphics at that.<br> The ability to communicate easily with other machines, including our own HX-20 and the advantage of using our fine range of printers, make the QX-lO a totally versatile system at a price you'll find impossible to equal.<br> £1735 plus VAT.<br> If you're looking at micros, look at the QX-IO. The system with all the answers. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD APRIL 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert (a bargain!) was published in the U.K. in September 1987</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''God created the world, DAI put it under CP/M''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SHOW BAG</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing: an era comes to the end" <br><br> "The Sirius era begins"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £149 IN JUNE 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Last sales in the UK. At the same time, a Commodore VIC-20 cost £139 and a Commodore 64 cost $229</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> POWER... IS EXPENSIVE!</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Megabyte Micro was a special version of the Imsai made with  16 x 64 KB RAM boards (Imsai just introduced this card) and a control board called Intelligent Memory Manager. A mapping configurator allowed each user to use its own protected RAM area. <br><br> Prices :<br><br> 64 KB RAM board Kit: <b>$2599</b>, assembled: <b>$3899</b><br> Intelligent Memory Manager board: <b>$299</b>, assembled: <b>$399</b><br><br>  To note: in 1977, 1 MB RAM costed... $62384!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (MAY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>No info in this advert about the display that could be used (TV, composite, colour, B/W?)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>From the magazine 'Micro Sistemas' of March 1983 <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.mci.org.br </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to John Kahler for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Christmas accounts" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>She seems so happy to have an Hit-Bit...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

item.description: 170Mb Quantum hard-drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 170MB QUANTUM HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This unit has an ICD Host Adapter.</blockquote>
Atari Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ATARI MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote>This hard-drive has a 30Mb capacity.</blockquote>

Inside the Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Seagate MFM 30 MB hard-disk Type ST-238<br> <b>(2)</b> Power supply<br> <b>(3)</b> Logical board<br> <b>(4)</b> Power and disk access LED's<br></blockquote>

Atari universal modem||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ATARI UNIVERSAL MODEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SX212 modem was one of the rare Atari peripherals that could be used with all the Atari computers range, from the 400/800 series up to the Falcon. It had both the Atari I/O ports for the 8-bit systems and a standard RS-232 connector for ST's<br><br> It was a 300/1200 baud modem compatible with the well-known Hayes 'AT' commands.<br> Cable and software was sold separately, depending of the computer used. </blockquote>

SML-804|||Laser printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SML-804</strong></font><br><strong>> Laser printer</strong><br><blockquote>The SLM-804 was actually a Kyocera F1000 printer but without neither on-board processor and memory nor buttons other than the on/off switch. It was first delivered with the Mega ST but could be connected on all of the ST series computers through a dedicated interface box.<br> The printer used the processing power and the RAM memory of the ST computer for printing at 8 pages per minute and 300 DPI. The paper tray held 250 sheets.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Francois Michaud</b> who donated us this printer.</p></blockquote>

SMLC-804|||Laser printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SMLC-804</strong></font><br><strong>> Laser printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>This interface allowed the SML-804 printer to be connected to any Atari ST holding at least 1 MB RAM.</blockquote>

emulator.name: Hatari
emulator.description: Hatari is an Atari ST emulator for Linux, BSD, BeOS, Mac OS X and other systems that are supported by the SDL library. More precisely, Hatari is an adaption of the WinSTon source code to the SDL library.
